Comment: No, the cold war was not relevant to the context. Apartheid was evil, supporting it was evil - cold war or no cold war. 
Nobody is saying it happened in a vaccuum (strawman fallacy), nobody is denying the cold war was part of the motivation for western governments supporting the NP government. 

The justification however is rejected as a valid one. It didn't make it okay to support the NP government. It didn't make it an acceptable trade-off.
Apartheid was no less evil than communism and supporting the one as a bulwark against the other was not a legitimate way to operate.

So if the cold war justification is rejected - then the cold war ceases to be a relevant factor in the history.

Frankly then - it is you who keeps hammering about something irrelevant, which everybody already knows. The only conceivable reason is that you DO believe supporting apartheid to fight communism was a legitimate thing to do. I don't. Coughlin was wrong. The west was wrong. You are wrong.

Comment: Wow.  Too many things wrong with your comment to cover them all.  To start off, Southern Manitoba drainage basis is the legacy of glacial Lake Agassz, which means it has habitually flooded since the end of the last Ice Age - over 10,000 years.  In recorded history, there were massive floods in 1826, 1852 and then later events in 1950 and 1997.  Are you trying to say that pre-industrial floods are the result of climate change?   It has been forever thus.  

I really object to people to blame every weather related event on "climate change" so they can grind their political axes online.   You demonstrate a complete lack of understanding of history, geography and logic with your comment.

Comment: Yeah but someone like me would. 

It takes a lifetime for second growth to become navigable (it is so choked off by a gazillion young trees growing close together, often different species than were originally cut). And wildlife loves space (to see predators coming and evade them) which is severely lacking in second growth. Old growth has a good balance of open space between mature trees and has a natural way of opening up exposure for forbs and other plants animals thrive on wherein dead or poorly rooted trees fall over and permit light through. Also look at the many small islands in Southeast with one or two trees on them, they grow completely differently. They grow out instead of up (since they don't have to fight for light and shoot up into the canopy). There isn't a problem in old growth that needs fixing and second growth certainly is not some value added product that anyone I know of would rather have, not hunters, not trappers, not bird watchers, etc...

Comment: Yes, I agree with you. I am not saying kill it (mandated programs) off completely, Some people will still need someone else to take care of investing for them. but even the option to choose a bank account, instead of letting the government do only SSI. Yes, CURRENTLY most fall into the later category. But does not have to be that . It depends on our actual commitment to really educating our population. If as kids were were taught investing just as much as we were taught basic math we would ALL be in a much better position to take care of our own long term investments. "Jimmy, do you want 5% candies interest with an investment ? Or are you happy with only 1% candies letting someone else use your money?" Yep, even 7 year olds would be able to figure that math problem out pretty easy. But it has to be taught as part of our fundamental and basic thought process, not the spend (on credit) and then earn (to pay off the credit) that so many people live like now. This is not sustainable.

Comment: While I do take your point, it can be argued that defence counsel have a duty to make use of every micron of wiggle room that can conceivably benefit their client's position.  If an opportunity exists, however minor and non-germane, and they fail to take advantage of it, they could be held to be negligent.

It is the judges who have the authority and the tools to take that burden of anxiety off the shoulders of defence counsel simply but shutting off the trivial lines of investigation and litigation, using the existing rules of procedure.  Of course, many judges refuse to do that because they appear to be terrified of the prospect of a rebuke from an appeal court.  Although we don't elect our judges, many of them are political animals clamouring to move up to the next court level.

Comment: You do understand that the SCC didn't ever clear Khadr of his convictions, don't you?
Aug. 10, 2005: Federal Court judge says Canadian agencies, including CSIS, violated Khadr’s rights by giving information from interviews with him to U.S. investigators.
May 23, 2008: The Supreme Court of Canada concludes Canadian officials illegally shared information about Khadr with the U.S.

Comment: It is not about being decent or not decent.
The 71% figure illustrates the difficulties experienced by the human mind in sorting our complicated issues.
Nobel prize winning psychologist Daniel Kahneman points out that our brain functions with two systems which drive the way we think and make choices: System One is fast, intuitive, and emotional; System Two is slower, more deliberative, and more logical.
Canadians, despite knowing that all of Khadr's rights were violated, and that he was underage, just do not care. Something over-rides their understanding that Kahdr was wronged
They are responding emotionally to images of threats, patriotism, fallen heroes, and, yes, racial identity. 
Fortunately, our court system operates on deliberation, logic and reason,  System Two which we has evolved over thousands of years.
Let's not regress to way we conducted our lives before we started walking upright.

Comment: I think you are grossly mischaracterizing Obamacare mandates. It required insurance to cover certain things, but which ones in particular would you consider wasteful or unnecessary? Routine care reduces long term costs, because conditions are acknowledged and managed early. It isn't like the ACA mandated free face lifts or LASIK for all. But getting people to the doctor regularly, not having an enormous cost barrier for checkups or to ask questions, all of those things are important components of quality medical care.

Covering cars is infinitely more simple than covering human health, and I don't think that drawing comparisons gets us very far. We do have minimum requirements though for what type of auto insurance you must carry if you want to drive a car, and I don't think having similar requirements for something infinitely more important and complex is unreasonable.

Comment: Lets talk about ACA for a bit. Obama implemented Universal Healthcare so everyone could get it. You get fined if you don't have it. As a result of this, companies that had health plans either A dropped their plan or B went to an ACA minimum requirement plan. These plans have deductibles that are roughly $2500 per person to $10,500 per family. Before, deductibles were $500 to $1000. 

More people are covered and the insurance companies get roughly $1000-$1200 per person per month either from you or subsidies. Given your deductibles, you still have to come up with your deductible before the insurance kicks in. Great, your covered, but you still have to pay.

From a high level, more people are still covered, but many of those people still can't afford to use it. All you did was reduce coverage and increase costs of health care. This is a broken system, which is why it is on the brink of collapse.

https://www.healthinsurance.org/blog/2015/11/16/is-obamacare-collapsing/

Comment: The problem with having an invasive species in the area is the replacement of the natural wild animal.  I'm not saying that this is perhaps a problem with turkeys.  An example of domesticated animals being introduced into the wild is rabbits.  Rabbits are not hares.  They are domesticated even the cottontail rabbit is a hare.  The balance of nature becomes disturbed when the less elusive "rabbit" is introduced into nature.  They are easier game for predators to catch because they don't have the instinct and blending ability that hares do.  Example of this is a black rabbit in the snow.  It might freeze but it can be seen!  What happens is the snowshoe hare becomes overpopulated because they are harder to catch by prey animals.  This leads to damage or loss of eatable items to support new hares.  Voila! When the starvation occurs what happens to the predators that have eaten all the rabbits and the hares have starved which decreases the population for predators to eat!  Make sense?

Comment: Unfortunately metro Vancouver have obsolete 3 light-metro systems; the old UTDC ALRT Expo Line and the Bombardier/SNC ART Millennium/Evergreen Lines which are barely compatible to operate and the Heavy-rail, built as a light-metro Canada Line, which is not compatible in operation with the other two. All three lines are capacity constrained, especially the Canada Line which can only operate 40m long trains because it platforms are 40m long and effectively has half the Capacity of the ALRT/ART lines which have station platforms 80m long. 

The cost to upgrade all three line to obtain higher capacities is about $5 billion, let alone the many billions of dollars needed to expand the system.

Comment: Thanks for this well-done op-ed. However, it is not only the mega-projects we should be paying attention to. Here in Southeast, consider these three road projects as the tip of an iceberg (just ones I happen to know about) for around $40 million. 

(1) The Shelter Cove Road, about $20 million for a 7-mile, one-lane gravel road going east from Ketchikan. That raised eyebrows in the on-line comments to a KRBD radio story last month, when the project went out for bids (not yet awarded).

(2) The $5 million, 6-mile Vallenar Bay road going across Gravina Island from Ketchikan's airport to a small State Forest timber sale that won't pay it off. It went out for bids a few days ago. 

(3) A 9-mile, one-lane gravel road to Sitka's Katlian Bay for $15 million. Alaska's DOT changed the purpose and need: the rock/gravel source for Sitka proved uneconomic to access; the road now will end elsewhere and be purely recreational. DOT wants to start construction soon.

Statewide, $$ for such boondoggles.

Comment: Stephen,

That first reading of all the questions and concepts you unloaded on us caused me to overlook your very essential opening question: Is that voice in your head you or God? The question belies the fact that many professed followers of God are not connected with Him. People don't like having to admit their distance from God and one of the common responses is claiming that God reveals things to them when He has not. God communicates with those who are willing to listen and obey, not those who claim to be His followers but do not obey. So one of the surest ways I've found to test such a claim is to see what change it makes in a person. Next is seeing if they are ministering in the power of the Holy Spirit as God instructed. If the power of God is not obviously making changes in their life or guiding their ministry, the "voice in their head" is most likely their own.

Comment: I like your columns, Leah.  

I'm 52 and decided to stop dying my hair a few years ago.  It's very grey now but with a good cut it looks really good; my husband loves it.    I decided to go grey mainly because I was really curious about what my natural hair looked like; I was pleasantly surprised when I finally let the dyed bits grow out.   I found that the dyed look made me look pale and I suddenly looked healthier. And I also wanted to be liberated from the dying routine as it drove me crazy; it's costly, insanely time-consuming, and unhealthy for me and the planet.   

I was really shocked by how liberated I felt by letting my hair go grey.

Comment: I've read the bill and followed it from day 1.  There's a lot to like and some not to like. It's a good start. The big areas they failed to address substantively are good time and parole.  Alaska in only 1 of 3 states that doesn't give good time to inmates who earn it. As it stands now we have the potential for 3 separate, expensive and time consuming court processes with any person who is on probation, parole ( common to be on both) and who may have committed a new crime, whether low or high level. Currently those just on probation and/or parole for, for example, a technical violation (like going out of off the area the PO has decided you must remain in as opposed to a non-technical  violation related to an actual new crime) through lengthy processes and can be given years depending on the whim of PO, prosecutor and parole board members.  Typically people are held in jail, often for many months, while the various issues are sorted out, innocent or not.

Comment: I've stated this previously, but it seems like time to repeat it.

I travel to Portland's VA Medical Center for medical care regularly at my expense (because the Anchorage VA Clinic is terrible in providing required services to women veterans). The vast majority of flights between ANC and PDX are jam-packed with slope workers coming to or leaving from work. I know this because I often speak with them in the boarding areas. Perhaps they buy a beer at the airport, but nothing else. Some of them absolutely hate Alaska. 

These workers pay income tax on very high salaries earned in Alaska to Utah, Oregon, Oklahoma, Arizona, and other states. One told me that if he has to pay income tax to Alaska rather than to his home state, he will quit slope work.

It's true that the proposed Alaska income tax would generate revenue from some Alaskans. It's also true that it would generate considerable revenue from highly paid slope workers who live and pay in other states.

Comment: Some of the forgotten real story of how the Hokulea was conceived and built originally-
Ben Finney, Anthropologist Who Debunked Theory on Island Settlement, Dies at 83
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/17/us/ben-finney-dead-hawaii-tahiti.html?_r=0
.
With Herbert Kawainui Kane, an artist, and Tommy Holmes, a local waterman, Professor Finney founded the Polynesian Voyaging Society in 1973 to study traditional Polynesian techniques of sailing and navigation. In 1974, he and several colleagues, including David Lewis, a New Zealand anthropologist who was an expert on ancient Micronesian navigation methods, set about recreating a facsimile of the double-hulled canoes used in ancient Polynesia, assembling a mostly Hawaiian crew and taking the vessel on test runs around Hawaii.
.
If the navigation went according to plan, the voyage did not. The canoe confronted fierce storms and becalmed seas. Even worse, cultural tensions arose. The Hawaiian crew threatened to burn the boat.

Comment: Thank you for taking the time to explain.  I remember when I was small (I am only 3 years younger than you) the tensions between the "old immigrants " (stari imigranty) and the newer arrivals.  There were so many levels of tension.  I actually remember my father mentioning on more than one occasion that much of the rancor of the newer arrivals toward the older arrivals was not right, because many of those whom we called "stari imigranty" were actually not immigrants at all, but were children and grandchildren of those who had come.  He said that they should be given credit for not forgetting their origins.  But my father's voice was a distinct minority, and I found it hard to appreciate his point of view, while I was dealing with many who made fun of me for speaking Ukrainian (because my parents insisted that this was the language that would be spoken at home and with siblings and cousins).  Now, my view is more like my father's.  But I've "become" my grandmother, so ...... :-)

Comment: I see this assertion a lot, but have never read why some people believe it to be indisputable truth.  It is not.

"As humans, we also need rituals"

SOME people may DESIRE to particiopate in rituals, but to say that ALL people "need" rituals is not true.  

In the context of religion, some desire some rituals in certain contexts (they don't "need" ritual), others pretty much forgo ritual (for example, Quakers).  

In the early church, the eucharist was a meal, presided over by someone chosen from the congregation, or by the head of household, who might have been either a man or a woman. No priests.

The rituals that have developed during the history of the RCC and christianity in general,  were developed by men, and sometimes have become a bit ludicrous. When any small change from the GIRM becomes a matter for civil war in the RCC, the notion of  the importance of 'ritual" has gone too far, becoming an end in itself that is often even at odds with true prayer and true spirituality.

Nobody wants to eliminate the name, we in fact would like to honor Pop Keeney in a way he has never been honored before.  We're proposing that the name be Pop Keeney Memorial Stadium, honoring both the Northshore students who went through the school system, as well as Pop Keeney himself.

Comment: "It presupposes that the underlying complaint was based on racial belief." I'm not sure what you mean by this. In fact I agree with the complainant that the Black Opinion site sows racial division.

"It also grandstands to say all speech should be acceptable" No it doesn't. Nor do I believe all speech is acceptable. We can have opinions on what speech is lawful, but ultimately courts (or arbitration bodies) have to decide (not you, me or an ISP) - that's the key point. ISPs should not have to be put into the invidious position of having to decide. What I should have made clearer is that Hetzner doesn't take-down based on content. If it gets a takedown request, it takes down irrespective of content else it risks being held liable under the ECT act.

Comment: Adams County didn't charge him - this is a 1st degree felony matter, the People of the State of Colorado charged him, and they charged him accordingly. What he is purported to have done, while however sickening and depraved it is, is the exact opposite of committing a hate crime. A hate crime requires that the bad actor, while operating out of a real or perceived hatred for an individual or for a class of people, and where the hatred is based on the victim's "race, color, religion, or natural origin," causes or attempts to cause extreme fear, great bodily harm, or death upon another. This guy went in to a store and just started shooting at everybody - he injured men, women and children from very different races, colors, etc... Because of his wanton and willful disregard for whom he killed, he's now qualified himself for the death penalty - which is a tad bit more serious than the few extra years he'd get for the hate-crimes.

McGoogan inadvertently stumbled onto a useful implication, however.  The UK no longer functions adequately as a quasi-unitary State governed in the final analysis from London, could function well as a federal State and the Canadian division of Federal and Provincial jurisdiction would be a worthy model to consider.

Sadly, the political and institutional creativity simply does not exist at present for the UK to seriously consider such a constitutional evolution.

Comment: Sorry, I tend not to get caught up in the petty "socialist" arguments that are important to progressives and conservatives because they are, in general, fruitless and unproductive.  "Socialism" is a spectrum, not a black and white thing.  By nature, government itself is a socialist enterprise.  What you guys really argue about is simply a matter of degree.  That's why I laugh when the right says "that's socialist" and the left says "socialism is good."  

That's why you're able to take wealthy Western capitalist countries and declare them to be "socialist," whereas places like Venezuela, Niger, Albania,  or Mongolia aren't used as examples for unexplained reasons -- even though they VERY accurately fit the definition of "socialism" that you are using.  

Why is that "socialism" only tends to work great in wealthy Western capitalist countries?   Vietnam had "universal health care" in the 70's, but that didn't seem to help them.  China too.  It was capitalism that changed everything.

Comment: "Religious liberty should unite us, not divide us"

These sorts of sayings and articles tend toward a sad superficiality....a nod, a moment of assent, a littering in of various points from "identity politics 101", but rarely anything more.  

Let me - hopefully others will join me - begin to correct this glaring gap in this article.   (and I hope this isn't the token "4th of July" article from NCR).

Let's take the superficial point and develop it in depth & practicality. 

Our pursuit of God should result in a greater union with Him, seen in many "fruits" of the Holy Spirit.    If we don't see the fruits, we should examine how we're supposedly pursuing God using our freedom.

Our use of our right (to pursue an intimate and lively union with God) is NOT to serve itself, but instead to spur on the work and mission of Jesus Christ in billions of small acts of Yes to Him. 

Our 'right' isn't the goal itself; it is rather a means to effect a duty..to love God in part by loving others.

Comment: Laicization is easier to understand if you think, not in terms of priesthood and sacramental ordination, but in terms of the clerical state and clerical status.  Laicization at least assumes the validity of ordination, but definitively removes the authority of the cleric to act as a cleric would except in emergencies and other closely defined instances (like teaching in a Catholic school, college, university or seminary).  The only other status that church law recognizes is the lay state, hence a man [sic] who has lost his clerical "privileges" is said to be "reduced to the lay state," to obviate any consideration of the laicized man exercising clerical or priestly functions without further action by the Holy See.

Comment: The worst effects of a Soviet high altitude test were from the electromagnetic pulse of the nuclear test on 22 October 1962 (during the Cuban missile crisis). In that Operation K high altitude test, a 300 kiloton missile-warhead detonated west of Jezkazgan (also called Dzhezkazgan or Zhezqazghan) at an altitude of 290 km (180 mi).The Soviet scientists instrumented a 570-kilometer (350 mi) section of telephone line in the area that they expected to be affected by the nuclear detonation in order to measure the electromagnetic pulse effects.The electromagnetic pulse (EMP) fused all of the 570-kilometer monitored overhead telephone line with measured currents of 1500 to 3400 amperes during the 22 October 1962 test.The monitored telephone line was divided into sub-lines of 40 to 80 kilometres (25 to 50 mi) in length, separated by repeaters. Comment: My sister recently turned 65, and after checking out her various options for Medicare, she chose a Medicare supplemental plan from insurance company A.
I'm on Social Security Disability, and I have a Medicare supplemental plan from insurance company B.
My wife will turn 65 next year, but not retire, and if it's to her benefit to switch to Medicare, she may well choose a supplemental plan from insurance company C.
Three people, three different insurance plans from three different companies.
Tell me again how "Medicare for all" eliminates costs and reduces redundancies?
Great, simple-sounding slogans are something politicians and activists from across the political spectrum adore, but unless "Medicare for all" is a significant ramp-up of the current benefits of Medicare, all that messy bureaucracy and redundancy is still there.

Comment: "Employers need to prepare for shift..."

Really?  If, as most would say, "it's all about the bottom line," why haven't they already contracted freelancers? I was a "freelancer" for over 25 years.  I understood these important employer benefits: 

1. Overhead diminishes.  No holiday pay, no CPP.
And, it gets better...
2. Hire enough "external talent," the business space shrinks with fewer full-time staff;  move to smaller--cheaper--commercial space. 
3. Pay only for production.  When freelancers take coffee breaks, lunch hours, "sick days", THEY pay for the time, their employers (clients) don't.  Employers often receive better performance, too; good freelancers ensure future work is by producing more...and better.
4. "Cream of the crop": In some cities, employers can access the very best talent the city has to offer. 
5. Got a really good employee? Tell him/her full-time work is over.  Kick start the process with a pink slip.

I used many of these reasons in my own sales pitches...

Comment: Regarding: "But the meta-question is, should the Catholic Church still believe that doctrine must be logically coherent? "
- This is a very good question.
- Doctrine or magisterial statements can be set aside when the facts of the matter show that either the doctrine is misconstrued, or that it has been so poorly stated as to be unhelpful.
- However as to the concerns of the 4cards and their hidden supporters the real issue is not 'if this, then not that', or 'there can be no 'ands' connecting magisterial statements and or doctrine', but that doctrine and magisterial statements are connected and found worthy in pastoral practice.  
- If the church has discerned that pastoral necessity requires a new 'lens' to see, then it is for the church to determine what lens that might be. That lens might not be everyone's cuppa but if the bishops with the Archbishop of Rome says it has merit, then we can only work for its success, until in practice it does not work anymore.

Comment: "Pope Francis understands that rules are one thing, but morality can not be determined by a set of rules."

Objective morality is determined God's revealed will for how we should live.  It is not a "set of rules" we simply learn by rote but is a relationship with Christ and an understanding of His commandments. These do not change according to the seasons and the age we live in.

Of course the Church has reframed its positions on many teachings. Doctrines have developed to meet new challenges in different circumstances. They have not departed from their core foundations. An older person is genetically the same as a child in the womb. Different, yet the same. 

Just what has changed in the nature of man that requires "a new sexual morality"? Western society has abandoned morality and Catholicism is now unpopular, so should abandon its teachings to become more "relevant"? How would this be squared with scripture which is replete with clear teachings?

Comment: Rogue Catholic---I'd agree with you somewhat.  But what about those pastors who have two or three parishes to care for.  I know a priest who in a matter of 10 days had 6 funerals from the two parishes that he has.  He doesn't just celebrate the Masses.  He met with the families to help them plan for the Masses for their loved ones, did a funeral vigil for each of the dead, then the funeral Masses, then the Committal Rites at the gravesites.  He teaches religion to the high school youth in both parishes and he's on the diocesan tribunal [marriages] where he goes at least once a week---more if needed.

His homilies are excellent and he's often called to give conferences at other parishes in the evenings.
Many priests have and do more than meets the eye of those who are only at the parish church, themselves, once a week.

Comment: For the last 20 months I’ve been filming a documentary about homelessness in Hawaii -to be broadcast on KGMB and KHNL this fall- so I’ve spent hundreds of hours with homeless people and even many of them argue that sit-lie laws are necessary.  I must have interviewed at least a half dozen who said, “You can’t have the homeless sleeping in Waikiki, that’s the heart of our economy.”  

It’s not heartless or patronizing to say that homelessness has an aesthetic impact, or that it affects bystanders’ sense of security.  It is not a materialistic corruption of values to state that those aesthetic and security impacts have hit our visitor industry.  If large numbers of tourists decide to give Hawai‘i a pass because of those concerns, the first people who will suffer will be local families; service workers at the bottom of the economic ladder who will lose their jobs.  I’ve heard estimates of as many as 200,000 people who are just one or two paychecks away from being homeless themselves.

Comment: That paper is out of date Christopher. We've had several peer-reviewed studies since then showing that we CAN now definitively link them to climate change, and one specifically showing hurricane severity being increased by climate change  - came out just last week.

Comment: You don't appear to be a very apt biologist, but rather a nasty troll spreading ill informed false moral equivalency.  Comparing a few thousand annual dropout sockeye salmon in directed fisheries in Bristol Bay to a large scale mechanized mining operation is just plain stupid.  These mining operations have a terrible track record in Canada, Eastern Europe, China, South America, and New Guinea.  The potential for irrevocable harm to the habitat is very real.  Dead sockeye salmon resulting from gilnetting that go unharvested will contribute to the nutrient cycle.  Moreover it is has been going on since the inception of the most productive commercial wild salmon fishery on earth for nearly 140 years and has not done harm to the sustainability of the run. Comment: O&M will imply taxes going forward and overall project feasibility. There are commissioning/startup costs and some small O&M gets into the capital expenditure budget, but shouldn't be that huge. Here's the part nobody is facing: look at above spreadsheets. On-going long term debt service is $400-500+ million per year. Add $200 million per year (hopefully conservative) estimated O&M. That's $600-700 million per year. Fare recovery is questionable. Even at 50% recovery, that's $300+ million per year unfunded liability. I'm not exactly sure, but I think our bus operates around 20-30% fare recovery, so the numbers could be much worse. Our GET surcharge now bounces around $300 million per year in these spreadsheets. So the projections are saying make the GET surcharge permanent or find another revenue source. Whoever follows Krookwell is going to be coming back for more. And this isn't even on the table now because Krookwell isn't releasing the full spreadsheets he has. Nuts.

Comment: You have a good point, but the discrepancy between electoral vote and popular vote overall only exists because small states have more electoral power per voter than big states.  This of course comes from the fact that small states have more per voter power than big states in the US Senate which translates into more electors per voter.  The swing state phenomena comes about not because of the electoral system per se, but because states currently award all electoral votes of the state to the candidate getting a simple majority of the popular vote.  If they awarded electors proportionately, the swing state phenomenon would also disappear.  Effectively, going to the popular vote is not necessary to eliminate the swing vote phenomenon.

Comment: The issue isn't whether a body part such as sperm or ovum or zygote is biologically human or alive. Each cell has a full complement of DNA. In the context of abortion, totipotency goes to the question of potential, not certainty of the end goal, which under perfect conditions produces a fully formed, viable person. The core issues are at what point does that occur in both a biological and legal sense, and who is legally in charge of the situation in the interim? I come down squarely on the woman's side. The woman is a legal person with all that implies. She has a right to privacy and bodily integrity. Is a zygote a person in the legal sense? No. Nor is a fetus or an embryo. In Roe v Wade, the Court decided that the state has an "important and legitimate interest in protecting the potentiality of human life" from the point of viability on, but that prior to viability, the woman's fundamental rights are more compelling than that of the state. I adhere to that position.

Comment: As a preface, I'm firmly in the free speech camp. His audience are adults, and if they truly find his statement offensive, they can change the channel or mute him.

That being said ... IF we're going to build a world where there's an offense-o-meter, and IF we're going to hold people responsible all over our modern society for their statements, and IF we're going to get into the odious business of forcing apologies, retractions, or possibly even pressuring people to step down or be dismissed, then it should be evenly applied. 

If this kind of comment would get someone fired if the target were NOT Trump, then it should get someone fired if the target IS Trump. In my opinion, forcing equal results for equal statements is the single best way to create more free speech advocates. You only have to unfairly see your job toasted once before you'll rethink your participation in viral campaigns to get people fired.

Comment: I'm happy that FPTP.  The candidate in each riding's election that receives the most votes, wins and becomes an MP.  One person, one vote.  Currently, the parties that occupy the centre obviously reflect the majority, which is why the two main parties are essentially coalitions of centre left and centre right.  So the work and negotiations needed to keep a PR government afloat, are done before hand.

What needs to happen before electoral reform is simply empowering MPs.  Whipped votes as they exist, should be eliminated, maybe with the exception of confidence votes, such as budget and throne Speech, which set the general mandate.  The PM would then need to do actual work to bring the party on side.    The Party Whip would then need to convince their party's MPs, not mandate, that they vote the party's preferred way.  MPs could not be kicked out of caucus if voting against.  MPs would be accountable to constituents and the impact of a "majority" government would be mitigated.

Comment: The PM killed the Northern Gateway pipeline at the same time he approved the Trans Mountain project.  If he had killed Northern Gateway in a standalone announcement, many Albertans would have been furious, and the media would have reflected that anger.  But the death of Northern Gateway has resulted in no negative reactions. Meanwhile, the PM knew that the U.S.-funded, west-coast environmental and indigenous groups would take their objections to Trans Mountains to the Courts, using the "lack of consultation with indigenous groups" as their main argument. Construction will not start until the Court process is completed, and that will take years. And in the end, the activist Courts, with their strong sympathies for aboriginals, will  likely declare invalid the process that led to the approval of the pipeline. The result? Trans Mountain will not be built during the PM's first term, if ever, and the PM can go into the next election with no new pipeline having been built to the west coast.

Logging was not allowed as it was a park. Nature sent in the pine beetle.

Unfortunately the beetle did not stay in the park. It destroyed thousands of square miles of forest in the BC interior. The accessible pine killed trees were logged. The inaccessible pine trees burned this year,long dead bone dry trees waiting for a hot dry summer.

The amount of carbon released by the dead trees & the fires make the Alberta oilsands look like midgets. The NDP is worried about a crude oil leak & ignores a major environmental disaster.

Comment: You are stating popular urban myth . A dear native friend of mine explained it to me years ago : He told me how it's nonsense saying that natives took care of the lands and  only hunted what they needed. Comment: Childhood obesity isn't primarily a function of stupid, lazy and irresponsible parents.   The problem is more complex than that and involves a number of issues including nutrient depletion in the soil which results in food that has fewer nutrients than it did a few decades ago.  

Nutritional deficiency is one of the insidious issues underlying widespread gains in obesity.   The subconscious brain deals with the nutrient deficiency in part by sending hunger signals to the conscious mind.

Pica is a nutritional problem that results when there are severe nutritional deficiencies.   Many people have something that resembles a mild form of pica when it comes to dietary nutrients which encourages both overeating and eating foods that aren't ideal.

That's what happens when predictions come true--and when advances in science make concrete what was only known vaguely at the time.  The post-Vatican II strengthening of moral theology and return to relevance of Catholic philosophers also helps.  But history does matter in some ways, and we now know that what dissidents have been telling themselves and us about the history of HV is simply incorrect and indefensible.

Comment: The past is the past. We need a plan to move forward together. That being said, I think "the rest of us" need to hear the indigenous community say "we are with you, this is how we can help build a stronger Canada together".  A separate indigenous peoples state is not the answer. There must be a "we" answer for all Canadians of which I include indigenous peoples. As well, each person, must contribute. Shelling out money isn't solving the problem. I know indigenous peoples view it as North America but we can't work with that. We need a Canadian answer.

Comment: The current rent controls are silly.

Better would have been to do like Paris and simply say that all condos/houses/apartments/business space that sit empty for more than 7.5months a year are required to pay a fee equivalent to 60% of fair market value for that building/space.

That is if you purposely  leave a space empty you pay 60% of market value. The incentive is on all these empty spaces to get filled, thus providing more supply to the market. Paris started at 20% and decided after a few years, that it wasn't enough so raised it to  60% these past few months. 

If anything, it gives municipalities money that they would otherwise have from more people consuming in those neighbourhoods, and can use that for better services to residents.

Comment: Price of 4L of 2% milk at Loblaws in Ontario is 40% higher than at Wegmans in NY. , after adjusting for currency and size of container.  A large chunk of of that is to cover the cost of owning production quotas.  The average Canadian dairy farm has 82 cows.  At $25K per cow, the production quotas are worth $2.05 million.  Somebody is paying for the farmer to earn a return on that investment.  Guess what - it is me and you!   

The value that production quotas have in our system is entirely artificial.  But if you want to get into the dairy business, you have to buy quotas at $25K per cow.  Now perhaps someone can explain to me why that is in the public interest.

If a cow produces 6000 - 8000 litres of milk per year and the farmer wants a 10% return on his $25K investment,  that works out to 30-40 cents per litre of incremental cost that every Canadian is paying.

Comment: Patricia,

A nomination goes through the  procedure: Introduction and Hearing in a City Council Committee and also in the full council hearing for adoption. This allows the public opportunity to support or protest a nomination.

Generally, a nomination sails through smoothly because the Council tends to defer to the office of the Mayor for its nomination. 

But, there have been a few instances where the nomination is delayed for  deliberations or even more rarely, the nomination is voluntarily withdrawn in response to opposition.  

Example: One of the most recent nominations that took a little more time to confirm was the Mayor's nomination of Max Hannemann to the Fire Commission.

Comment: Michael, I am going to give you an English lesson.  This is the text of the Alaska Constitution, Art. VIII, Section 4: 

"Fish, forests, wildlife, grasslands, and all other replenishable resources belonging to the State shall be utilized, developed, and maintained on the sustained yield principle, subject to preferences among beneficial uses."

See the comma after the word "principle"?  That modifies the words that come before the comma.  So, the first part of the sentence about sustained yield is modified.  To, "...subject to preferences among beneficial uses."

Without this modification to the sentence Alaska could be just a big game farm where we kill ALL the predators.  But because the sentence is modified, the Constitution requires the animal populations be managed with due consideration to ALL of the possible beneficial uses.  NOT just hunting.

Comment: I predict a few things restaurants will do to accommodate a higher minimum wage.

Automation is one. I dined today at a trendy(ish) restaurant where the waitress used a tablet to take my order. It would not be terribly inconvenient for that restaurant to reduce its wait staff, leave tablets at the table, and ask diners to key their orders themselves. 

Another response would be to make employees incur their own training costs, perhaps through a community college program rather than on-the-job training. No doubt the Ministry of Education would be keen to provide this new educational opportunity.  In six short weeks they could teach you to bus tables, operate a debit machine and, for us old folks, make correct change. 

A third, more vicious response could be to impose a service charge or higher prices in lieu of tipping wait staff directly. Money that now goes directly to wait staff would then be diverted to fund mandated wage increases. Unkind? Certainly. Likely? Oh yes.

Comment: Progressives like Bill Maher argue, correctly, that indiscriminate liberalism is as responsible for the rise of Trump as right wing conservatism. We're all well aware that neanderthals - white supremacists, religious bigots, gun-toting anarchists, et al - form part of Trump's hard core base. These are people who can never be persuaded by rational argument - so extreme and entrenched is their ignorance. 

Unfortunately the alt-right are mirrored by on the left by a group that is overly myopic, irrational and obsessed. These people hold, for example, that any immigrant is a good immigrant and that we must accept everyone who claims to be a refugee. This mentality has created division in the U.S. and even more tension in the E.U. where unchecked immigration and porous borders gave way to Brexit and may presage a resurrection of fascism. 

The general case should be decided on the numbers, which are lacking. But there's no shortage of anecdotal evidence that accommodation can go too far.

Comment: Goodness......You need to read the history of election fraud.  You need to check the statistics regarding voter fraud.  You will find there is absolutely NO basis for your claims.  

Study the extremely decentralized system of balloting in the U.S.  First, you will see the Electoral College system which breaks the system into fifty different segments.....each fully independent.  Then each State is broken into precincts; further decentralizing the process.  Each State and each precinct has fully accountable systems for vote counting.  It would take a nation-wide, state-wide and precinct-wide conspiracy to "rig" an election.  

I don't mean to be insulting, but if you feel the process is rigged and, additionally,  President Obama did't really win in 2012, there's really no purpose in my attempting to have a rational conversation with you. 

I can only say I'm sorry that you have so little faith in our country.

Comment: Here is a list of the estimated Federal Debt (accumulated deficits), by year,  from the 2015 budget, 2016 budget and 2016 fall fiscal updated.

2015/16: $617.0B / $619.3B / $616.0B
2016/17: $615.3B / $648.7B / $642.0B
2017/18: $612.6B / $677.7B / $669.8B
2018/19: $610.1B / $700.5B / $695.7B
2019/20: $605.2B / $718.2B / $715.0B

So as you can see the debt numbers from the Fall Fiscal Update are very slightly better, albeit entirely due to the fact that they got rid of the $6B/year "contingency" line-item.

Among the eight most similar such universities, as designated by the Oregon university system, UO is dead last, trailing far behind the University of Washington's $550,000-per-professor average."

"Four of UO's closest competitors, the flagship universities of Iowa, Michigan, Virginia and North Carolina, have twice as many tenure-track faculty per student."

"University of Oregon's six-year graduation rate for undergraduates, 66 percent, is also dead last among the eight most similar universities."

 This is the U of O analysis,  not some right wing nut job.

Comment: "Journalism only exists because of audience interests."

The basic need of the audience is to be informed in what exists beyond their noses and ears, while also wanting to be entertained with novelty.

One of the trends in journalism is old formats, such as newspapers and TV news programs are shrinking, while being replaced by digital formats that offer the convenience of briefness, can be consumed while on the go, and leave one with the satisfied feeling of being informed without any real exertion.

Like fast food, fast info feeds, can't really nourish the modern media consumer with  a broad, in-depth understanding of the interrelationships that constitutes "news events".

Due to stressful economic conditions that force most people to be too busy and indiscriminate about their "News" inputs - the quality of journalism will continue to decline while emotional titillation masquerading as information will flourish.

I worry.

Comment: Aikens history went from the Paiutes to the arrival of settlers in the 1840's bypassing the trapping period from 1810-40. A relative of mine, Louis Pichette, trapped the region for Hudson's Bay Co. He was the first Euro-American in Northeast CA (1820). 

The Paiutes were considered to be more primitive than many other tribes in the Oregon Territory. This was because of their transitory camps and desire to avoid contact. Resources were scarce with little surplus. They rarely traded but raiding was an honored practice. 

What ties the op-ed and its comments together is the different rate of exploitation practiced by natives and Euro-Americans. The trappers were a bridge. Over-harvesting the regions fur bearers infuriated the Paiutes. 

A Marxist interpretation adds to this thesis. Capitalism ramps up the rate of resource  extraction and often leads to systemic degradation. This is the Euro-American legacy.  The opinions here reflect different views on its value.

Comment: The last born in my family was a Down Syndrome person. Back then I had never heard that term; he was "retarded", "mongoloid". Some kids, even adults made fund of him. Neighbors who knew him, us, were great. As an early teen I was embarrassed by him. I could only relish though in watching his joy in being who he was. I wept when sadness or anger overflowed in what I perceived was frustration for what he couldn't do as others could.  He was different.  He was outside the norm and being outside that norm had consequences.  Not one of them included "evil" - even though, sadly, erroneously, some people contended that "retardation" was a visitation of God's ire for some transgression. 
I have grown to see Jesus so much more clearly in Down Syndrome than in most people. 
Think about it - outside the norm is intrinsic to nature. That is "natural law". God is telling us something about judgment and judging, about ourselves.
We don't have to be stuck in a backward cultural bias and miss so much.

Comment: It certainly wouldn't be difficult for healthcare providers to establish a set price for procedures that took contingency circumstances into account. Comment: There is no account that holds funds earmarked for the SS trust funds, that money has long since be spent.

When the trust funds are called by SS, the Treasury department is required to redeem them. In redeeming the trust funds the Treasury either borrows money to pay them thereby increasing the national debt or they pay the money from the general fund which is mostly funded by income taxes.

"Once you eliminate Social Security (SS), your claim that "entitlement programs" are driving deficit spending falls completely apart. Even more so when you eliminate the funded parts of Medicare." No it doesn't, currently no entitlement programs are fully self-funded (including SS) as you attempted to imply. Federal entitlement programs are being funded by borrowing and income taxes any assertion otherwise is simply false.
Entitlement programs consume about 67% ($2.5 trillion) of the $3.7 trillion federal budget, that fact is indisputable. https://www.cbpp.org/research/federal-budget/

Comment: Classic example of the unintended consequences of Dodd Frank and other financial regulations in the aftermath of the 2008 recession. 

Compliance with 22,000 pages of new regulations requires an army of lawyers on staff.  Big banks can afford that but small community banks - which used to provide more than half of small business lending like, say, construction loans - go out of business.  So in trying to solve the problem of "too big to fail", regulators have helped to create even bigger banks. 

The article nicely frames the issue in terms of supply and demand, but stops short of fully exploring the government distortions of a free market on the supply side.

Comment: There are countless others, but a couple of anecdotes are enough for an online discussion. As a late rebuttal to your points...

1) Banting: Needed lab space, dogs, a student, and eventually collaborative help from a biochemist for his research. How can one disassociate the university/lab from the discovery? He not only needed tools and infrastructure, but also additional academic help. 

2) Genome editing is the future of therapeutics. There are some proteins that are simply too damaged to be fixed by small molecules. Function can only be recovered or impeded to a certain degree in these structurally flawed proteins. Cutting out the genes and replacing with appropriate alternatives will be our next-gen tools. Whether CRISPR has the specificity to achieve this is uncertain, but it is a major advancement (or hot discovery). 

3) Drug companies, bingo. Much like other aspects our capitalistic framework - socialism for the rich, individualism for the poor.

Comment: In response to proposed changes at Lord Hill Regional Park (LHRP), Pilchuck Audubon Society (PAS) implemented avian monitoring to better understand the importance of this large acreage park to birds.I helped establish the monitoring effort and appreciate being a part of the park planning. I know mountain biking (MB) is a beloved outdoor sport here in the NW but, if needed, PAS advocates that any new MB facilities be placed in areas not sensitive to birds. We also want our advocacy to be based in real/current data.Through our monitoring we discovered that the abundance & diversity of birds in LHRP exceeded our expectations, including species dependent upon large patches of mixed  forest habitat. All users of public lands leave some impact but one of our concerns was planned loss of habitat at LHRP to develop the space for MB use and the introduction of fast moving vehicles (some MB users) that can impact breeding success. Wildlife + people... looking for healthy solutions for both.

Comment: In Ontario, section 147 of the Highway Traffic Act (HTA) says any “vehicle travelling upon a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at that time and place shall, where practicable, be driven in the right-hand lane.  Normal doesn’t mean the speed of other traffic. It means the speed limit, according to the Ontario Provincial Police. The speed limit is the maximum speed at which vehicles should be travelling, i.e. 100 KPH. So, if someone else is at 130 KPH the speed limit is still 100 not 130. This also applies to HOV lanes. The Minister of Transport also stated this under questioning in the Legislative Assembly. The law needs to be changed and  then maybe we'll have a little less road rage. The solution, privatised photo-radar everywhere, especially around schools. The province gets a percentage of the fines as do other drivers clustered around the offender when the photo is taken. Motorist share can be put in an MTO account to offset the cost of plate renewals. Let fools pay.

Comment: I'm a professional (physician). In the process of unincorporating. There is a lot of exaggeration on both sides. I have done some pretty careful calculations....I save about $3000 - $5000/year via incorporation. I also pay ~$2500 extra in accounting/legal fees. The people who really lose on these changes are very high-priced specialists who income split with young adult children and a say-at-home spouse as well as the lawyers and accountants who have been carrying out the various schemes. Most primary care physicians will be surprised at how little they are impacted....While I do think some federal bureaucrats need a reality check (and changes to) their bloated benefits/pensions, physicians still have RRSPs, RESPS, TFSAs...one can save ~$36 000 a year using these, which if invested smartly e.g. ETFs will generate a very comfortable retirement and education paid that most Canadians don't enjoy....and if one still insists on a private corporation, there are still personal pension plans.

Comment: The 2007 Oregon Legislature authorized $458 million for two mental health facility projects, one in Salem and one in Junction City. The facilities were built by Hoffman Construction, Oregon's largest general contractor... $1.8 billion in revenues in 2014. These two facilities were intended to provide 960 beds. If the designated $458 million was spent entirely on construction, leaving nothing for operational costs, that's paying $477,000 per bed and , at Junction City, $425,000 per year per patient for yearly maintenance.

Seems a little high to me, but then I'm not a mental health care expert, just a taxpayer.

Comment: A few, major errors;
Tick attachment times for numbers of the infections are very short, the tick borne viruses in the 15 minute range, babesiosis (lives in the ticks salivary glands) a few hours, and the "Lyme"  spirochetes in as little as 6 hours, or less.

Washing clothes after returning from walks does nothing to kill ticks, they love humidity. Instead ALL clothes and shoes should go directly into a drier at high heat for 15 minutes, completely desiccating or drying out ticks.

Please note also the CDC surveillance criteria, (buy their own admission) only "captures" roughly 10% of the cases. Their criteria is so strict that most cases are not recognized.

We need to speak up and help sort out the myths versus reality on many aspects of the tick borne diseases, including the mindset that "Lyme disease" is a singular infection, hard to catch and easy to fix. "It" is none of the above, and in long term or chronic cases ALWAYS involves multiple synergistic diseases.
Lane Poor
RI USA

Comment: The PM is assuredly not a one person show in this era of huge, complex, costly government that began in the 1930s.

But if the leader is to lead rather than being a token leading in the way a ship's figurehead is said to be leading the ship other executive abilities and talents are also required.   Otherwise the "leader" is really a sham and a fraud on the electorate.

In addition to interpersonal skills, a leader needs to be highly intelligent, capable of articulating to the people and to his team a vision and values that inspire them, able to set priorities, milestones and accountability for their achievement, and able to radiate confidence and courage in tough times.

So degrees are much less important than previous executive experience as a governor, minister, general, or private CEO.

Comment: Transient rentals aren’t the sole cause of rising rents. Decades of successful HTA-led marketing and advertising, perhaps a billion people worldwide (but especially in Asia) love Hawaii, and are a few clicks/taps away from full property information. It will only become easier for the wealthy to move cash as freely in real estate as they can buying and selling stocks. In the most desirable global locales like Hawaii, locals aren’t competing against their neighbors to buy or rent property anymore. If 1% of the planet's population has the cash to buy property in Hawaii (70 million people), what do we do? Do we expect these homebuyers to rent to unstable long term tenants who trash the property, are bad neighbors themselves, or are living paycheck to paycheck and end up behind on rent? Read Richard Florida's take on winner-take-all cities. We are experiencing a global geographic redistribution of the "creative class", and people who aren't part of that class are relocating.

Comment: I suggest that you read up a bit on the history. There is a mnemonic about the fates of Henry VI's wives: "Divorced, beheaded, died. Divorced, beheaded, survived." Henry VIII beheaded two of his wives, Anne Boleyn (on trumped-up charges) and Catherine Howard (on quite legitimate charges -- adultery by the queen was treason under the statute). Of the others, two were divorced (one for non-consumation), one died in childbirth and the sixth outlived him.

Henry actually had solid grounds for an annulment. His father, Henry VII, arranged a marriage between his eldest son, Arthur, and Catherine of Aragon. A few months afterwards, Arthur died. The king wanted to keep the Catherine's dowry (over a million in today's currency, which would have had to be repaid out of the Privy Purse). So he decided to marry his second son, Henry, to Catherine. There was a problem: Under Church marriage law, one cannot marry one's deceased spouse's sibling.

I smiled a bit when I read a comment by another poster in this thread that said something like "It's ok to steal from me if you love me." If they can't even meet the legally required minimums on such an easy project, why should they be considered anything but anti-bike? Comment: The writer has anchored his argument firmly and fully in one foundation, and that is "Reconciliation".

I would be curious to hear his views on the set of Canadians who dismiss the foundation upon which he builds.

In other words, there are Canadians who dismiss "Reconciliation", who reject it is an un-needed and un-warranted and irrational entity, one that is maladaptive and unproductive. 

For them, the way to a better future for all Canadians is not to take measure of this past wrong and that past wrong. For them, it is is ridiculous to pretend you can bring back together two beings who (hello) were never together in the first place. For them, it is an impossible dream to think that the wildly disparate views of two beings can somehow (roll eyes) become compatible with one another if only there was more in the way of self-flagellation and public shaming.

To them, "Reconciliation" is a laughable, manipulative farce, the word's political usage a sad joke on its dictionary meaning.

Comment: In large reverberant churches such as the one you described there is only one type of sound system that works effectively, and that is small speakers in every pew voiced low so as not to be amplified by the natural acoustics of a large reverberant building. The problem is, most sound engineers have no skill or experience in working in such an acoustical environment and so inevitably put in the wrong kind of system which only makes matters worse. These sound professionals are only accustomed to working in totally "dry" acoustics and so are unprepared for the challenge of dealing with a "live" room. I've attended masses where such a sound system is installed, and you can both understand the spoken word and hear music with a lot of acoustical reverberation, which is good for much church music, especially of the classical variety such as you might expect to hear in a cathedral.

Comment: First off, where's the non-partisan link documenting your claim that Cohen refused to provide documentation?

And second, why are you whining about the lack of an accuser's proof for anything, when your whole retarded premise was it wasn't necessary for them to do so, and was the sole responsibility of the person accused to prove he wasn't guilty?

This goes fully against the long standing legal tenet known as "The Presumption of Innocence", which is defined as "a principle that requires the government to prove the guilt of a criminal defendant AND RELIVES THE DEFENDANT OF ANY BURDEN TO PROVE HIS OR HER INNOCENCE."

This works in conjunction with another requirement mandated in statutes that states the government MUST PROVE THE CHARGES AGAINST THE DEFENDANT "Beyond a Reasonable Doubt", which is a due process requirement that persons suspected of a crime BE PRESUMED INNOCENT.

The two principles are tied together, and can not be separated- like you are ignorantly trying to do now.
